lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project dialog first)
1. Set up the correct JDK version, as follows:
1. Click `Configure` > `Structure for New Projects` and then `Project Settings` > `Project` > `Project SDK`
1. If JDK 11 is listed in the drop down, select it. If it is not, click `New...` and select the directory where you installed JDK 11
1. Import the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.

1. After the importing is complete, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()`. If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below:
* The Duke program is an application which can store, display and check Tasks.
* There are 3 types of tasks, ToDo, Deadline, Event.

throw new DukeException("Date specified is of wrong format! Use YYYY-MM-DD format!");
throw new DukeException("Date specified is of wrong format! Use YYYY-MM-DD format!");

throw new DukeException(" OOPS!!! No integer index detected!");
* Returns the targetString when the find command is input.

* @return Command of sub-type depending on the command given.

* This class deals with handling storage on the TaskList.\n
* There is a load method to import in the saved data from the specified file path.
* There is a write method to export the data to the specified file path.
* Imports the TaskList data from specified file path.
* @throws DukeException when file not found, or file format is wrong.
throw new DukeException("No save file detected!\nCreating fresh new task list...");

* Exports the TaskList into a txt file at specified file path.
* @throws IOException when there is an error due to writing the txt file.
public void write(TaskList tasks) throws IOException {
* Represents a Deadline Task which is a subclass of Task
* with its corresponding deadline date stored as by.
* Represents a Event Task which is a subclass of Task
* with its corresponding event date stored as at.
* Represents a Task with its corresponding taskDescription and a isDone status
* based on whether or not the task has been marked as done by the user.
* Sets the isDone status of the Task object.
* Returns the isDone status of the Task object.
* Returns an icon for the corresponding isDone status of the Task object.
* Overriding toString() method for this Task Object.
* Represents a list of tasks stored in an ArrayList of Task.
* Marks a Task as done in the TaskList.
* @param index of the Task to be marked as done.
* Returns the size of the current TaskList.
* Returns a new Task at the specified index.
* @param index of the Task to be returned.
System.out.println("Your task list is currently empty!");
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* Finds and prints the Task containing the target.

System.out.println("There were no matching tasks found!");
* Finds and prints the Task(s) occurring on the LocalDate date.
System.out.println("No tasks occur on that date");
* Represent a ToDo Task which is a subclass of Task.

System.out.println("Create new deadline by specified date:\n\tdeadline <taskDescription> /by <YYYY-MM-DD>");
System.out.println("Create new event at specified date:\n\tevent <taskDescription> /at <YYYY-MM-DD>");
System.out.println("Mark task at specified index as done:\n\tdone <index>");
System.out.println("Delete the task at specified index:\n\tdelete <index>");
System.out.println("Find tasks that occur on specified date:\n\toccur <YYYY-MM-DD>");
System.out.println("Exit the program and saves the current TaskList:\n\tbye");
